Sarah R. McLaughlin is volunteer at the COVID Tracking Project supporting various data visualization initiatives. She has a background in Epidemiology/Biostatistics and is currently working at a Boston-based SaaS company.

Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Vaccines Begin to Arrive as Cases and Deaths Keep Rising: This Week in Long-Term Care COVID-19 Data, Dec 16

lede.lede: Cases are up and known deaths in long-term-care facilities are the highest they’ve been since late May.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Artis Curiskis is outreach & reporting co-lead at the COVID Tracking Project and collaboratively runs the CTP special projects Long-Term Care COVID Tracker and City Data.
Conor Kelly is the director of data analytics at Hanover Research.
Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Kara Oehler is outreach & reporting co-lead at the COVID Tracking Project and collaboratively runs the CTP special projects Long-Term Care COVID Tracker and City Data.

blog_post.title: What We Know—and What We Don’t Know—About the Impact of the Pandemic on Our Most Vulnerable Community

lede.lede: Residents of nursing homes and other long-term-care facilities suffered an outsized impact from COVID-19. And yet we still don’t know how big of an impact, because so much data is missing or incomplete. What we do know makes plain that we failed to protect this community—and at great cost.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Alexis C. Madrigal is a staff writer at The Atlantic, a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the author of Powering the Dream: The History and Promise of Green Technology.

blog_post.title: Giving Thanks and Looking Ahead: Our Data Collection Work Is Done

lede.lede: While our work to compile COVID-19 data has concluded, we will continue to share research, analysis, and documentation in the months ahead. We are enormously grateful to the hundreds of volunteers who made this work possible.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Artis Curiskis is outreach & reporting co-lead at the COVID Tracking Project and collaboratively runs the CTP special projects Long-Term Care COVID Tracker and City Data.
Kara Oehler is outreach & reporting co-lead at the COVID Tracking Project and collaboratively runs the CTP special projects Long-Term Care COVID Tracker and City Data.

Dave Luo has an MD/MBA and is a Data Science and Data Viz lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Federal COVID Data 101: Working with CMS Nursing Home Data

lede.lede: Here’s what we know about the only federal dataset on COVID-19 outcomes in long-term care facilities.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Alexis C. Madrigal is a staff writer at The Atlantic, a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the author of Powering the Dream: The History and Promise of Green Technology.
Kara Schechtman is Data Quality Co-Lead for The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: How We Hope Vaccines Will Be Tracked

lede.lede: The federal government seems poised to provide high-quality data on vaccinations, but even a minimal dataset must answer key questions about who is getting vaccinated.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Artis Curiskis is outreach & reporting co-lead at the COVID Tracking Project and collaboratively runs the CTP special projects Long-Term Care COVID Tracker and City Data.

blog_post.title: Vaccine Distribution Data in Long-Term-Care Facilities Needs to Be Public

lede.lede: For the last month, the public has had minimal visibility into the roll out of COVID-19 vaccines to long-term-care facilities. Last week, South Carolina published the names of nursing homes and other long-term-care facilities where residents and staff have been vaccinated. States—and the CDC—should follow suit.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Artis Curiskis is outreach & reporting co-lead at the COVID Tracking Project and collaboratively runs the CTP special projects Long-Term Care COVID Tracker and City Data.

blog_post.title: Surge Continues as Northeast and West Coast Cases Spike: This Week in Long-Term Care COVID-19 Data, Dec 9

lede.lede: Long-term-care facilities continue to bear the brunt of this deadly virus. The latest surge continues in the Midwest and South, as COVID-19 cases in the Northeast and West begin to spike.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Artis Curiskis is outreach & reporting co-lead at the COVID Tracking Project and collaboratively runs the CTP special projects Long-Term Care COVID Tracker and City Data.

blog_post.title: Long-Term Care Deaths Pass 100,000 as Outbreaks Surge: This Week in Long-Term Care COVID-19 Data, Dec 2

lede.lede: Despite messy reporting due to the Thanksgiving holiday, this week saw continued high numbers of cases and deaths in long-term care communities. But relief may be on the way, as a CDC committee recommended that long-term care residents and staff be first in line to receive the coronavirus vaccine.

blog_post.title: Nation Still Grappling with Long-Term Care Outbreaks as New Cases Double: This Week in Long-Term Care COVID-19 Data, Nov 24

lede.lede: Nearly 40 percent of new COVID-19 cases in long-term care facilities came from the Midwest, and just three facilities in Wyoming were home to half of that state’s new resident and staff cases, a dire reminder of how easily COVID-19 spreads within close-contact environments.

blog_post.title: Cases Race Past Previous Highs: This Week in Long-Term Care COVID-19 Data, Nov 17

lede.lede: With COVID-19 cases surging across the country, long-term care facilities experienced their largest increase in six months. The LTC case surge is concentrated in the Midwest, mirroring the pattern of the US pandemic as a whole.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Artis Curiskis is outreach & reporting co-lead at the COVID Tracking Project and collaboratively runs the CTP special projects Long-Term Care COVID Tracker and City Data.

blog_post.title: The Third Wave of COVID-19 Deaths in Long-Term Care Facilities is Here: This Week in Long-Term Care COVID-19 Data, November 11

lede.lede: In October, eight percent of long-term care facility residents diagnosed with COVID-19 died. The rising cases of the past few weeks are resulting in the highest number of deaths in months as states and facilities fail to protect these most vulnerable Americans.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Whet Moser is a freelance writer in Chicago.
Conor Kelly is the director of data analytics at Hanover Research.

blog_post.title: Introducing the Long-Term Care COVID Tracker: Tracing COVID-19’s Dramatic Toll on a Uniquely Vulnerable Population

lede.lede: Our new dataset shows how COVID-19 has travelled through the nation’s long-term care facilities. The virus has killed one out of every 28 long-term care residents in the United States.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Rebecca Glassman has a Master’s in Public Health and is a public health researcher in academia. Opinions expressed are her own.

blog_post.title: Cases Stop Dropping and the Midwest Heats Up: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Sep 3

lede.lede: After five straight weeks of sharp declines in new cases of COVID-19 in the United States, we’ve leveled off again. Reported tests are up about 5 percent, but are actually dropping in the Midwest, where three states—Iowa, North Dakota, and South Dakota—are driving an uptick in new cases. This week we also launched a new dataset that looks closely at the toll of COVID-19 in nursing homes and other long-term care facilities.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Kara Schechtman is Data Quality Co-Lead for The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Federal COVID-19 Testing Data Is Getting Better

lede.lede: The federal government improved its state and county-level COVID-19 PCR testing data since we analyzed it in February. Here’s an update on those changes and what we hope to see next for the data.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Alice Goldfarb leads The COVID Tracking Project’s part in The COVID Racial Data Tracker, and is a Nieman Visiting Fellow.

blog_post.title: Federal COVID Data 101: What We Know About Race and Ethnicity Data

lede.lede: Publicly available federal race and ethnicity COVID-19 data is currently usable and improving, although it shares many of the problems we’ve found in state-reported data.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: How Not to Interpret COVID-19 Data

lede.lede: Beware of dating schemes, data dumps, weather events and other issues that can lead to mistakes that confuse the public.

childMarkdownRemark.html: The COVID Tracking Project is a volunteer organization launched from The Atlantic and dedicated to collecting and publishing the data required to understand the COVID-19 outbreak in the United States.

blog_post.title: Federal COVID Data 101: How to Find Data

lede.lede: Here’s where and how you can find COVID-19 data now that The COVID Tracking Project has ended.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Zach Lipton is a San Francisco software developer and Data Infrastructure co-lead for the COVID Tracking Project.
Dave Luo has an MD/MBA and is a Data Science and Data Viz lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Federal COVID Data in a Single Stream

lede.lede: We’ve created a bit of code that helps combine federal testing, case, deaths, and hospitalization data into a single spreadsheet.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Dave Luo has an MD/MBA and is a Data Science and Data Viz lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

Catherine Pollack is a third year PhD candidate in the Quantitative Biomedical Sciences program at Dartmouth College. Her dissertation research combines data science, epidemiology, and public policy to combat online health misinformation.

blog_post.title: Federal COVID Data 101: Working with Hospitalization Numbers

lede.lede: Here’s a walkthrough of the Department of Health and Human Services’ dataset and what you should know about it.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Jennifer Clyde is a data quality and data entry shift lead at the COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Federal COVID Data 101: Working with Case Data

lede.lede: Here’s a walkthrough of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) daily case dataset and what you should know about it.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.

blog_post.title: Where to Find Simple COVID-19 Data for the US

lede.lede: As The COVID Tracking Project approaches its final day of data compilation on March 7, 2021, we are recommending a selection of federal data sources to people who want a quick and easy way to keep an eye on the pandemic.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Joseph Bensimon is a member of the COVID Tracking Project’s Data Quality team.
Quang P. Nguyen is a PhD candidate in the Department of Epidemiology at Dartmouth College.

blog_post.title: Federal COVID Data 101: Working with Death Numbers

lede.lede: The CDC provides two different datasets regarding COVID-19 fatalities. Here’s a walkthrough of how they compare to each other and to The COVID Tracking Project’s data.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Artis Curiskis is outreach & reporting co-lead at the COVID Tracking Project and collaboratively runs the CTP special projects Long-Term Care COVID Tracker and City Data.
Kara Oehler is outreach & reporting co-lead at the COVID Tracking Project and collaboratively runs the CTP special projects Long-Term Care COVID Tracker and City Data.

Dave Luo has an MD/MBA and is a Data Science and Data Viz lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Federal COVID Data 101: Working with CMS Nursing Home Data

lede.lede: Here’s what we know about the only federal dataset on COVID-19 outcomes in long-term care facilities.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Kara Schechtman is Data Quality Co-Lead for The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Federal COVID Data 101: Working with Testing Data

lede.lede: At least three different federal agencies share testing data for SARS-CoV-2 in at least four different places. Here’s a little about where that data comes from, what each dataset has to offer, and how you can use the datasets best in light of their large differences from state-provided data.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Rachel Glickhouse is a New York-based journalist who works on project management and impact tracking at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Learn More About Using Federal COVID-19 Data with The COVID Tracking Project

lede.lede: In February and March, we’ll hold a series of free trainings to help anyone who uses our data to understand existing federal numbers.

blogContent.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Despite making up less than 1% of the nation's population,","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" people living in nursing homes and other long-term-care facilities account for ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"at least","marks":[{"type":"bold"},{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" 35% of the nation’s COVID-19 deaths","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". But getting even enough data to make that statement has involved a laborious process of stitching together unstandardized datasets produced by the 56 states and territories we track. With our efforts ending on March 7, 2021, we’d like to introduce you to The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Nursing Home dataset","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://data.cms.gov/stories/s/COVID-19-Nursing-Home-Data/bkwz-xpvg/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"—the ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"only ","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"dataset from the federal government about COVID-19’s effects on the staff and residents of long-term-care facilities. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"heading-2","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"What’s in the CMS data","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"CMS Nursing Home dataset","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://data.cms.gov/stories/s/COVID-19-Nursing-Home-Data/bkwz-xpvg/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" includes 120 metrics spanning confirmed COVID-19 cases and deaths, suspected COVID-19 cases and deaths, PPE availability, staff shortages, COVID-19 testing, number of occupied beds, and more, all of which are listed in the ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"data dictionary","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://data.cms.gov/stories/s/COVID-19-Nursing-Home-Data-Data-Dictionary/8rzn-j9yt/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" for the dataset. The dataset is accompanied by ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"summary notes","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://data.cms.gov/stories/s/COVID-19-Nursing-Home-Data/bkwz-xpvg/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", an ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"FAQ","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://data.cms.gov/download/b62a-ieuz/application%2Fpdf"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"detailed descriptions of CDC/CMS quality assurance processes","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://data.cms.gov/download/bqa5-3dzf/application%2Fpdf"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", and ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"documentation","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://data.cms.gov/stories/s/knxu-fe3r"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" that includes mapping tools, data export options, API documentation, and email addresses for user support.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Nursing home facilities have been ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"required to report","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.cms.gov/files/document/qso-20-29-nh.pdf"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" COVID-19 data to CMS since May 17, 2020. This data is reported through CDC’s National Healthcare Safety Network (NHSN) ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"module for long-term-care reporting","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.cdc.gov/nhsn/ltc/covid19/index.html"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". Facilities can submit data multiple times a week but are required to submit at least once a week. This data has been published weekly by CMS since May 24, 2020. CMS warns that the first week of data (for the week ending May 24, 2020) should not be used for trend or longitudinal analysis. Nursing homes, assisted-living facilities, and care facilities for the developmentally disabled are all ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"eligible","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" to report data to the NHSN’s COVID-19 Module, but only nursing homes are ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"required","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" to report. CMS’s nursing home dataset, as the name suggests, reports data ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"only","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" from nursing homes. (The CMS reporting week goes from Monday to Sunday, so a dataset row labelled 5/31/2020 represents the reporting week of May 25 to May 31.)","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Notably, the CMS data includes a resident census, or the number of residents who live in a given nursing home, which is a crucial reference point.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"The documentation provided by CMS includes several important cautions, including ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"warnings that erroneous reports may be suppressed","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", and that ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"facilities can correct data after submission","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". The documentation also cautions users of the data to remember that ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"access to COVID-19 testing has been limited","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" throughout the pandemic, which necessarily shapes the data itself.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"heading-2","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"What’s missing in the CMS data—and what’s better","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The CMS Nursing Home dataset was first published on May 24, 2020, over three months after the first COVID-19 death in LTC residents was confirmed at Life Care Center of Kirkland, Washington. Facilities were not required to backfill historical COVID-19 cases or deaths, and it appears that many did not.","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"embedded-entry-inline","content":[],"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"3NcEqKzloOgizAmN9GoxjK","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" As a result, CMS’s dataset—like our own long-term-care COVID-19 data—is a known undercount of cases and deaths. Because the CMS dataset was first established in May and does not include mandatory historical backfills, it should not be used as a cumulative representation of the impact of COVID-19 on nursing home residents. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Additionally, the CMS data does not attempt to provide a comprehensive view of all long-term-care facilities in the country: It includes only nursing homes, which are federally regulated, and which house an estimated 1,347,600 residents, according to ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"data released by the National Center for Health Statistics","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/data/series/sr_03/sr03_43-508.pdf"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" in 2016. Assisted-living, resident care, and other kinds of care facilities not counted as nursing homes house an estimated ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"811,500 residents","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/data/series/sr_03/sr03_43-508.pdf"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block","content":[],"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"52cy9XXexLcMkRjO4gtZXJ","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"These two factors—the May start without mandatory backfill, and the restriction to federally regulated facilities—appear to explain why the CMS dataset reports about 43,000 fewer COVID-19 deaths for long-term-care facilities than states report themselves, according to our compiled data.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"A note for researchers:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" According to a brief review on March 3, 2021, we found that 23 states currently distinguish between nursing homes and other types of facilities in facility-level data on their own websites. Where states publish data on assisted living facilities and other long-term-care facilities separately from nursing home data, it may be possible to consider both federal data on nursing homes and state-reported data on other facilities to arrive at a more complete estimate of a state’s experience with COVID-19 in long-term-care facilities. ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"(Researchers undertaking such a comparison should carefully study the data definitions and time periods available in both state and federal databases and take care to note that different datasets are being used to estimate the pandemic’s effects in the various facility types.)","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Unlike the long-term-care COVID-19 data reported by the states, the CMS Nursing Home dataset appears to be largely standardized. The data we were able to compile from states included disparate data definitions, categorizations, data ranges, and levels of granularity. We saw states use varying definitions of COVID-19 cases, deaths, and outbreaks, as well as facility types, and some states didn’t break out resident and staff cases and deaths, making cross-state comparisons nearly impossible. ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"The federal dataset’s standardization of these and other metrics is a substantial advantage for data users.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"heading-2","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"How CMS Nursing Home data compares to COVID Tracking Project data","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"As noted above, the CMS Nursing Home dataset includes data on a subset of all long-term-care facilities—","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"only federally regulated nursing homes","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". This difference complicates direct comparison, but it’s useful to roughly measure the gaps in the two sets of figures. For example, in comparing what percent of US COVID-19 deaths occurred in long-term-care facilities, the numbers in the CMS data would account for 27 percent of the nation’s deaths, while the figures in the COVID Tracking Project LTC dataset represent at least 35 percent of the nation’s deaths as of our most recent update. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block","content":[],"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"7kxN8rsZfqMVsKD9hqsNeG","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"In many states, the trend lines for the two datasets are very similar, even when the absolute numbers vary substantially. Since the CMS dataset represents only nursing homes, we would expect the CMS figures to be lower than state-reported figures for states reporting a wider range of long-term-care facilities. This is not always the case, however: ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"The CMS data for 12 states currently includes a larger number of deaths for nursing homes alone than the states report for all long-term-care facilities on their own websites","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":".","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"embedded-entry-inline","content":[],"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"6bQvBfSWiOZjpv2Ud5UOCI","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" These unexpected findings ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"could","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" be the result of definitional differences, unstandardized state reporting, or artifacts of our compilation process, and suggest that additional analysis of data definitions and time periods represented in the state-reported and federal data in those states is worth further inquiry by researchers. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block","content":[],"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"16FL359oaRBE2zsUymFQRM","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"For the state of Arizona, where ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"a court ruled","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.azcentral.com/story/news/local/arizona-health/2020/05/29/judge-rules-arizona-nursing-home-covid-19-records-private/5283835002/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" that the state could keep data on COVID-19 in nursing homes and other long-term-care facilities confidential, the CMS dataset provides the only direct measure of the pandemic’s effects on LTC residents in the state. (Because Arizona’s state health officials do not report this data, The COVID Tracking Project has used public information from Maricopa County and Pima County, the state’s largest counties, to provide a partial estimate of cases and deaths in LTCs.)","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"heading-2","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"How to use the CMS Nursing Home dataset","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Working with the CMS Nursing Home dataset can be a challenge because the file contains nearly 600,000 rows of data, each with 120 columns, and grows larger each week. We’ve created a practical ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"user's guide","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://docs.google.com/document/d/1tfl--gGliJKuDXsYxgxiIrN4Tx1e5xzPQ7Ji1m7qhYk/edit?ts=603d38fe#"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" to help data users learn how to acquire the data through CMS’s data hub or their API. Most other questions can be answered by the federal ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"documentation","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://data.cms.gov/stories/s/knxu-fe3r"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" or other documents linked from ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"the dataset’s landing page","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://data.cms.gov/stories/s/COVID-19-Nursing-Home-Data/bkwz-xpvg/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":".","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"heading-2","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Bonus data: Vaccination Data for LTCs","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Although The COVID Tracking Project has never compiled vaccine data, we have been monitoring available sources for this data since vaccinations began in the US. ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"Long-term-care vaccine data is available from four different sources","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", each at a different level of detail. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"In every state except West Virginia, residents of long-term-care facilities are mostly vaccinated through the CDC’s ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Federal Pharmacy Partnership for Long-Term Care Program","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/covid-19/long-term-care/pharmacy-partnerships.html"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". (West Virginia developed its own program and offers no public data on long-term-care vaccinations.) In this program, most doses are administered by CVS and Walgreens, with other local pharmacies participating in some areas. Federal vaccine data from the Federal Pharmacy Partnership can be found on the ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"CDC’s COVID Data Tracker","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#vaccinations-ltc"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":".","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The CDC provides vaccine data by state with total first doses administered and total second doses administered, but this state-level data is not broken out by staff and resident doses. The CDC only breaks out staff and resident doses for total US doses administered in the program. The state-level data is updated daily, and is downloadable from the tracker as a spreadsheet. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block","content":[],"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"rVRk4xF87ttPDfes0xpbK","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Data collected by the Federal Pharmacy Partnership program is recorded in the federal vaccine reporting system called ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Tiberius","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.technologyreview.com/2021/01/27/1016790/covid-vaccine-distribution-us/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". Tiberius data provides a view of how many doses residents and staff have received at individual facilities, but the Tiberius data is currently made public on a daily basis by only one state (that we know of): ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"South Carolina","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://scdhec.gov/covid19/covid-19-vaccine-allocation"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". The Tiberius data includes indications of which pharmacy held vaccine clinics (CVS or Walgreens), the city, the facility name, the total number of beds at the facility, first and second dose by residents, and first and second dose by staff. Our researchers have been able to obtain unpublished Tiberius data directly from several states, many of which provide it upon request. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block","content":[],"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"2I5IqlwttgiQwMpkY0zRH6","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The final source of vaccine data for LTCs comes from CVS and Walgreens themselves. CVS updates data on weekdays ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"around 4pm ET","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://cvshealth.com/covid-19/vaccine-information/vaccination-data"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" and Walgreens updates their ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"data daily around 6pm ET","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.walgreens.com/topic/findcare/long-term-care-facility-covid-vaccine.jsp"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". The two pharmacies data is collected from the clinics they hold at facilities.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"CVS provides state-level data by facility type (Nursing Homes and Assisted Living/Other LTC Facilities), total doses administered, and number of facilities assigned per state. Walgreens provides state-level data by facility type, date when the program started per state, number of assigned facilities per state, and total vaccines administered. ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"Neither company breaks down data by staff and residents.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"heading-2","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Additional federal datasets for cross referencing","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"CMS also offers several related datasets that can be useful for researchers and reporters looking at COVID-19 in nursing homes. We’ve included a brief list below and created ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"an example of how to link multiple datasets together with CMS data","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ETgFTL6XCcalRPJSKCObKIjne3MewHmR3QJm-KBTTZE/edit#gid=1078562138"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" using the CMS Facility ID.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block","content":[],"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"DwvoMba4EUF67osnaDw52","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}}},{"nodeType":"heading-2","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"How federal data can be better","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The CMS Nursing Home dataset is already excellent in many respects, but we have a few recommendations for making it even stronger. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"unordered-list","content":[{"nodeType":"list-item","content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Get the historical data. ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"The federal government should require nursing homes to backfill their historical COVID-19 data to include the earliest data they have. The pandemic’s deadly first surge in these facilities is still only patchily documented and ill-understood, and compiling a complete record of known cases and deaths will be an invaluable resource for researchers and policymakers. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"list-item","content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Develop a comprehensive reporting system for all long-term-care facilities.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" State and federal authorities should work together to ensure that all long-term-care facilities—not just federally regulated skilled nursing facilities—are required to report pandemic data to a single authority. Without such a change, it will be impossible to track the true effects of COVID-19—and future pandemics—on this highly vulnerable population.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"list-item","content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Provide current facility and population counts.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" The federal government should provide public estimates of the current number of LTC facilities in the United States by facility type, along with estimates of resident and staff populations. Without this information, it’s very difficult to contextualize the effects of the pandemic—or of vaccination programs—in these facilities. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"list-item","content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Release the facility-level vaccination data.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" The federal government should release the vaccination data gathered in the Tiberius system at the state and facility level, along with any available information on quality assurance and anomaly detection. Even if this data is imperfect, detailed information about the vaccination rollout in LTC facilities is too important to remain secret.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Although they are both far from comprehensive, the long-term-care dataset we’ve compiled from states and the CMS Nursing Home dataset tell the same story: ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"US long-term-care facilities were not prepared for a pandemic like COVID-19, and the losses in these facilities have been devastating.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" With more than 2.5 million US LTC staff and residents now fully vaccinated, we have seen major reductions in COVID-19 deaths in these facilities, and we expect to see these numbers continue to drop. After working closely with this data for the better part of a year, we believe that both better data and better—and fully funded—regulations will be required at every level of American government to ensure that the unthinkable losses we saw in these facilities this year can never happen again.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Research from:","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" Zach Lipton, Jonathan Gilmour, Julia Kodysh, Conor Kelly","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

footnote.footnote: For example, Connecticut began releasing death data on COVID-19 in nursing homes on their [official state site](https://portal.ct.gov/Coronavirus/Nursing-Homes-and-Assisted-Living-Facilities) on April 16, 2020, but our researchers suspect that some of those early deaths and cases are not included in the CMS dataset: In early June, the state of Connecticut reported 809 more nursing home resident and staff deaths on its own site than appeared in the CMS data. Our researchers also reviewed data from facilities known to have reported early data on state websites to see if differences persisted between their state-reported data and the corresponding CMS data—which they did.

image.title: LTC Federal 101 - deaths chart
image.description: 2 lines showing cumulative deaths in long-term-care facilities by week for CTP and CMS respectively. CTP shows more total deaths (172,905 to 129,748).

image.title: LTC 101 federal post - percentage chart
image.description: 2 lines showing the percentage of cumulative COVID-19 deaths that happened in long-term-care facilities by week for CTP and CMS respectively. LTC deaths make up 35% of all COVID-19 deaths in the CTP data set and 27% in the CMS data set.

footnote.footnote: The 12 states are Alaska, Alabama, Arkansas, Hawaii, Iowa, Kentucky, Missouri, Ohio, Oklahoma, Tennessee, West Virginia, and Wyoming.

image.title: Line charts comparing COVID Tracking Project data to CMS data for 52 states and territories.
image.description: Line charts comparing COVID Tracking Project data to CMS data for 52 states and territories. In many cases, CMS data follows a similar trajectory but is lower than state-collected data.

image.title: Screenshot of CDC vaccination table
image.description: Screenshot of the COVID-19 vaccination data table for Long-Term-Care facilities located on the CDC website.

image.title: Screenshot of the Tiberius vaccine reporting system data table
image.description: Screenshot of the Tiberius vaccine reporting system data table showing vaccine data from individual pharmacy locations across the country.

table.table:
| Dataset Name         | What it has                                              | Where to find it                                     |
|----------------------|----------------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------|
| Provider Information | Star ratings, staffing hours per resident, profit status | [https://data.cms.gov/provider-data/dataset/4pq5-n9py](https://data.cms.gov/provider-data/dataset/4pq5-n9py) |
| Penalties            | Fine amount, date of penalty                             | [https://data.cms.gov/provider-data/dataset/g6vv-u9sr](https://data.cms.gov/provider-data/dataset/g6vv-u9sr) |
| Ownership            | Ownership type, owner title                              | [https://data.cms.gov/provider-data/dataset/y2hd-n93e](https://data.cms.gov/provider-data/dataset/y2hd-n93e) |
| Quality Measure      | Quality of resident care                                 | [https://data.cms.gov/provider-data/dataset/djen-97ju](https://data.cms.gov/provider-data/dataset/djen-97ju) |

lede.lede: Here’s what we know about the only federal dataset on COVID-19 outcomes in long-term care facilities.
